textPlain: A CS degree costs something like 124 yrs salary for someone in a low income nation—and it’s a much longer harder road. I’m not AI’s biggest fan, but arguably, this type of tech actually narrows the gap. Even if it’s expensive.
Luckily, a ChatGPT Pro subscription is not mandatory. It's not like one can't live without it.

I don't think it's got anything to do with ChatGPT, especially given that it has a generous free tier too, let alone a about much cheaper (than the pro) plus tier.It's an international economy problem, not an AI problem.

One issue I have with the widely used metric of 'Productivity per hours worked' - if I have a second apt I rent out to Bob for $1000, I have a 'productivity' of $6.25 per hour 'worked', despite nobody producing anything and nobody working for any length of time.

> low-incomesomeone has to pay for the servers at the end. are you asking for openai to subsidize ChatGPT Pro for low-income countries? Since OpenAI is for-profit entity focussed on profits, I don't think it might be a wise idea financially for OpenAI to do so.
Regrettable, but did it take o3 mega pro to find out about real and nominal value? Even something a trivial as an iPhone is a far bigger purchase if you're not on a Bay Area salary.
A pack of cigarettes in Norway is virtually unaffordable.
I think one step at a time.There are still many countries where digital literacy is very low.So first step is to ensure everyone has internet/mobile phone/laptop and knows how to use them.
Wait till you find out how much an apartment costs!
Do you have a source for this claim?
Well it was founded as a non-profit

I take one look at our smartphone/social media addicted society and the damage that does and think of the parallels of forcing opium on a population in the 19th centuryNot that the rural third world don’t already have phones. Whether they are engineering to be as addictive as crack like in the west I’m not sure.
